repnme.cdata!:
Nicaragua - Financial Sector Adjustment
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated as
            satisfactory, and sustainability is likely. Overall
            performances by the Bank and the Borrower are considered
            satisfactory. Lessons learned with regard to state bank
            privatization include the following: Successful
            privatization of state banks is possible even in a very
            difficult environment. Sequential auction of individual
            branches, as occurred with the National Development Bank
            (BANADES), is an approach that allows privatization of a
            large state bank while ensuring continuity of service. The
            sale of 100 percent of the state bank should be sought.
            Retaining partial state ownership can limit the probability
            of attracting a high-quality buyer and may weaken the
            bank's post-privatization performance. Once the
            decision to privatize a bank has been adopted, the
            day-to-day management should be replaced by a competent
            transitional management or very closely supervised by
            independent parties. The quality of the buyer is the most
            important element to ensure a good post-privatization
            outcome. Pre-qualification requirements should restrict
            participation to well capitalized and experienced banks. A
            management contract with a bank is a poor substitute for
            sale of ownership. Intensive IDA involvement in supervising
            the process is needed, particularly in a setting with weak
            governance institutions. Loan proceeds should be disbursed
            only after careful review of the privatization transaction.

5081389.trustfund:
TF022477-PHRD-ECONOMIC RECOVERY CREDIT
            2/BANK EX.,TF029370-PHRD -PUBLIC POLICY &
            ADMINISTRATIVE REFORM,TF028717-IDF-NICARAGUA PUBLIC SECTOR
            FIN. MGT.

repnme.cdata!:
Nicaragua - Financial Sector Adjustment
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Financial Sector Adjustment Credit
            Project (FSAC) for Nicaragua will provide a loan of
            $70,000,000 to the Government of Nicaragua for its
            structural adjustment program. The objectives of the program
            aim to: 1) carry out a major reform of the state banking
            sector; 2) improve financial intermediation, especially in
            rural areas; and 3) improve the regulatory framework for
            private banking. In order to achieve these objectives, the
            FSAC project will support measures to: 1) maintain a stable
            macroeconomic framework; 2) restructure the state banking
            system, including the closure of one state bank and the
            capitalization by private investors of another state bank;
            3) foster private banking presence in the rural and
            agricultural sectors; and 4) strengthen the regulatory
            framework for, and supervision of, private banking. These
            measures will allow the Government of Nicaragua to address
            major obstacles to sustainable private sector led growth and
            mobilize additional balance of payments support.
